entry.title: MRP MD01N: Inconsistent Component PR Creation and Stock Consideration Behavior with/without Subcon.
entry.content:
Dear team,

 

Issue Summary:
When executing MRP Live (MD01N), the system shows inconsistent behavior for component purchase requisition (PR) creation and stock consideration depending on whether Subcontracting MRP Area configuration is active.

 

Prerequisite Configuration Setup:

  • MRP Area type (MDLV-BERTY) = 02 â€“ Storage Location is configured.

 

Prerequisite Master Data Setup:

  • Component material Issuing Storage Location (STPO-LGORT) is maintained in the Bill of Materials (BOM).
  • Corresponding Storage Location type MRP Area is assigned in the component material master MRP1 view (MDMA)

 

Requirements summary:

Requirement#

Description

1

Component PR to be created at BU level MRP Area - When the component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT) is set in the Bill of Materials (BOM), the component purchase requisition (PR) should be created at the BU level MRP area of Component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT).

2

Component Stock of BU level MRP Area should be considered - When the component material Issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT) is set in the Bill of Materials (BOM), the component stock of storage location of respective BU level MRP area should be considered, and system should not consider neighbor BU level MRP area stock.

3

Component Stock at subcon Vendor Location should be considered during planning run â€“ Unnecessary PR should not be created if sufficient component stock is available at Subcon Vendor location

 

 

Observed Behavior:

Scenario

Req#1 â€“ PR created in Storage loc. MRP area

Req#2 â€“ Stock from Storage loc. MRP area considered

Req#3 â€“ Stock from Subcon vendor location considered

Without Subcontracting MRP Area configuration

Yes

Yes

No

With Subcontracting MRP Area configuration

No

No

Yes

 

Expected Behavior:
The MD01N should:

  • Create PRs in the storage location type MRP area of issuing storage location (STPO-LGORT)
  • Consider stock from the same MRP area.
  • Consider stock from the subcontracting vendor location.

Scenario

Req#1

Req#2

Req#3

With or without Subcon MRP Area configuration

Yes

Yes

Yes

 

Preference:

  1. Preferred Option: Meet all three requirements without activating subcontracting MRP area configuration.
  2. Alternative Option: Meet all three requirements with subcontracting MRP area configuration active.

 

Business Impact:

  • Unnecessary PRs are generated even though there is enough stock in subcontracting vendorâ€™s storage location.
  • Available component stock at the vendor location, Storage location level MRP area is not effectively utilized.
  • leads to excess procurement, higher inventory, and inaccurate MRP planning results.

 

Questions to SCN.

  • Is there any SAP standard configuration or master data setting available to meet all three requirements simultaneously?
  • Could you please confirm whether there is any SAP Note available to achieve this behavior?

 

Thanks & Regards,

Manoahr

entry.title: Re: Mass Download Line Items in General Ledger
entry.content:
This is the current limitation in Excel spreadsheets from Microsoft. This is the workaround:

In the APP: Display Line Items in General Ledger filter for posting date as "Last quarter" and click go. Then export the data to Excel. If the same error still does come up then reduce it to one month. If this is still too large then reduce it to 2 weeks. KBA 3639629 - In Display Line Items in General Ledger app, large amounts of data canâ€™t be exported at one time

entry.title: SAP to Collaborate with AWS to bring the SAP BTP ABAP Environment to Arm-Based AWS Graviton
entry.content:
Authors: Steven Jones (AWS), Sonja LiÃ©nard (SAP)

The key to SAPâ€™s innovation and adoption success has always been its openness, supporting diverse hardware platforms, networks, and technology ecosystems, while offering flexible deployment options for customers operating in mixed and heterogeneous environments. This principle extends to the ABAP Platform and especially the BTP ABAP Environment, which powers next-generation ABAP Cloud applications and extensions. Beyond this openness, SAP is leveraging innovative technologies like AWS's ARM-based Graviton processors. Today, we are excited to announce the evolution of that partnership:

SAP and AWS will collaborate to bring the SAP BTP ABAP environment to Arm-based AWS Graviton processors.

 

A Longstanding History of Co-Innovation in the Cloud

Since 2008, SAP partnered with AWS to help customers leverage cloud innovations. In 2023, we announced that SAP HANA Cloud runs on AWS Graviton, a custom-built chip by AWS that delivers price, performance, and energy efficiency benefits for cloud workloads. By initially migrating SAP HANA Cloud to AWS Graviton3-based Amazon EC2 instances, SAP has seen up to 30% better compute performance for analytical workloads and lowered its compute carbon footprint by an estimated 45%. Building on these experiences, SAP and AWS have been continuously innovating to further improve the performance of SAP HANA Cloud.

Driving Flexibility and Performance

SAP BTP ABAP environment is the platform as a service offering for ABAP developers. Itâ€™s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud applications.

Initial tests have shown positive results for ABAP on AWS Graviton architectures, demonstrating strong performance and efficiency gains. With the extensive breadth of Amazon EC2 instance families available on Arm, SAP will be able to select the right instance type and size optimized for ABAP workloads and leverage this diverse portfolio for maximum instance flexibility for our customers.

Why Arm and AWS Graviton?

With AWS Graviton3-based instances, SAP experienced up to 35% price-performance improvement for analytics workloads, and a reduction of the compute carbon footprint of SAP HANA Cloud workloads. With AWS Graviton4-based instances, weâ€™ve seen an up to 25% additional performance improvement for analytical and up to 40% additional improvement for transactional workloads compared to AWS Graviton3-based instances.

Now, with the next AWS Graviton5-based Amazon EC2 M9g instances, weâ€™ve observed a 35-60% increase in the performance of our OLTP queries on SAP HANA Cloud in a single generation. Based on the performance improvements demonstrated in SAP HANA Cloud with AWS Graviton processors, SAP is confident the SAP BTP ABAP environment will also leverage AWS Graviton technology to deliver similar benefits.

A Strategic Partnership for Sustainability

This new collaboration continues our shared commitment to sustainability. SAP is a signatory of Amazonâ€™s Climate Pledge and has accelerated its own sustainability commitment to 2030. Our journey with AWS Graviton aligns perfectly with those goals, and we are eager to see what additional improvements in energy efficiency we can realize together in the future.

Whatâ€™s Next?

Porting the SAP BTP ABAP environment to AWS Graviton involves adapting its cloud-native architecture, including containerized services and runtime components, to Arm. SAP and AWS teams will continue developing, testing, and working on performance optimization pipelines to ensure a seamless experience for customers.

We look forward to sharing more updates on this project and the value it brings in terms of performance, reliability, and sustainability. Stay tuned as we continue this journey together.

entry.title: Delivery Note/Package Query
entry.content:
Hi,
I am trying to generate a query comparing the quantity on a delivery note line items to the quantity on the delivery note packages.  I only need the lines that are different in the results.

I have the query:
SELECT T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", SUM(T1."Quantity") AS "DelQty", T2."ItemCode", SUM(T2."Quantity") AS "PackQty" FROM ODLN T0 INNER JOIN DLN1 T1 ON T0."DocEntry" = T1."DocEntry" LEFT JOIN DLN8 T2 ON T1."DocEntry" = T2."DocEntry" AND T1."ItemCode" = T2."ItemCode" WHERE T0."DocNum" ='15079'
GROUP BY T0."DocNum", T1."ItemCode", T2."ItemCode"

But when I try for the HAVING clause - Get No Results I tried a couple

a) HAVING SUM(T1."Quantity") > SUM(T2."Quantity") OR SUM(T1."Quantity") < SUM(T2."Quantity")
b) HAVING SUM(T1."Quantity") <> SUM(T2."Quantity") 

If I say HAVING SUM(T1."Quantity") = SUM(T2."Quantity") - I get the lines that the quantities match

Any help would be greatly appreciated

entry.title: Re: Adding Country/Region after Deploy in CBC System
entry.content:
Hi!

In SAP Central Business Configuration, adding a Country/Region to the Scope is a supported Self-Service activity, meaning it can be performed directly by the user.

To proceed with the Country/Region addition, the Workspace must be in the â€œScope and Organizational Structureâ€ phase. If the Workspace is currently in the â€œProduct-Specific Configurationâ€ phase (after deploying the Workspace), the Define Scope app must be Reopened before continuing to the Country/Region addition.

For the detailed steps on how to perform the Country/Region addition, please refer to the following KBA: 3438273 - How to Add a Country/Region in SAP Central Business Configuration Workspace - SAP for Me

Additional information can be found in:

  • Country/Region-Specific Scoping and Configuration | SAP Help Portal
  • Changes via Edit | SAP Help Portal

Best Regards,

entry.title: Re: unable to find license catogary for purchase requestion
entry.content:
Hi,

Please refer to the KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/0003631390

  • The app My Purchase Requisitions- New can be used. This new self-service procurement app serves to offer the employees or casual users a consolidated one-stop solution that provides a quick, intuitive, and efficient shopping experience.
  • This app is available using the business role SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE_PROCUREMENT and business catalog SAP_MM_BC_SSPPR_MANAGE_PC. 

Also as per KBA  3631973 - The app 'Display Purchase Requisitions' is Advanced priced category instead of Self Serviâ€¦ 

Certain apps such as Display Purchase Requisitions require an "Advanced" license due to the complexity and breadth of functionality they offer. These apps enable users to perform advanced tasks and often include features beyond basic transaction processing. This contrasts with "Core" or "Self-Service" apps, which focus on standard business processes or user-specific tasks.

In this scenario, the Self-Service procurement app 'My Purchase Requisitions- New' can be used. With this app, as an employee or casual user can do the following:

  • Create, view, edit, copy, and delete self-service purchase requisitions.
  • Track the status and process flow of your purchase requisitions.
  • Confirm the receipt of goods.
  • Return the received goods in case of any issues or defects.

Thank you,

SAP Support

entry.title: How to remove order reasons
entry.content:

Is it possible to remove order reasons on the configuration activity ? I have some unwanted order reasons (with empty description) and I'd like to delete them.

Best regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to remove order reasons
entry.content:
Hello,

The order reasons can be deleted when they're not being referenced by any document.

You can check how many orders reference an order reason by going to the 'Manage Sales Orders' and filtering by the concerned order reason. If there's no sales order for the order reason, then it can be deleted.

Kind regards.

entry.title: SAP Developer News December 4th, 2025
entry.content:
DESCRIPTION

UI5con Bengaluru postponed

  • https://www.linkedin.com/posts/openui5_ui5con-bengaluru-in-january-2026-activity-7401570604036018176-jvVK/

Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build

New btp CLI command group to manage destinations

  • Details: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/christian-lechner-inthecloud_sap-btp-terraform-activity-7400073359939530753-tA6W/

Launch of Data Architect Learning Journey â€“ Foundational

  • Become a Data Architecture Powerhouse: Your Foundational Learning Journey: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/launch-alert-become-a-data-architecture-powerhouse-your-foundational/ba-p/14281620

CHAPTER TITLES

0:00 Intro

0:10 UI5con Bengaluru postponed

0:33 Field report from UKISUG Connect 2025

1:29 Lessons from building an AI coding assistant for SAP Build

2:49 New btp CLI command group to manage destinations

3:25 Launch of Data Architect Learning Journey â€“ Foundational

4:30 TechEd 2025 Fun Look

7:18 Devtoberfest Winner Mansi Dixit

Transcription

00;00;00;02 - 00;00;06;02
Thomas
This is the SAP Developer News for December 4th, 2025.

00;00;06;05 - 00;00;31;22
Nico
Hi everyone, and welcome to the SAP Developer News. Important announcement. If you are planning to attend UI5Con in Bangalore in December. Unfortunately, due to unforeseen circumstances, the event had to be postponed. There are targeting mid January now. Check out the UI five column website for all the updates. And registration opens soon, so keep an eye on that and I hope to talk to you soon.

00;00;31;24 - 00;00;34;27
Nico
Bye.

00;00;35;00 - 00;01;00;22
DJ
Good morning from Birmingham. Day three the last day of UKISUG Connect 2025. It's been great. We had on the first day, on a some day a whole load of workshops, hands on workshops. Great discussions took place there as they did on Monday. Full of talks, great keynote and today we've got a keynote. I've got to believe shortly to join that keynote and listen in to what Timo has to say today.

00;01;00;25 - 00;01;24;13
DJ
And then there's going to be a series of talks as well. It's been great. Okay, so connect is always a great conference to attend. It's connections, reconnection with sharing and learning together. And it's been a fun and honorable time here because I get workshop on Sunday and it's talk on Monday, which seem to go down well, I'm not sure it's all a bit random, but anyway, that's how it goes.

00;01;24;15 - 00;01;29;18
DJ
Fantastic. Well, signing out from UKISUG Connect 2025 and see you soon.

00;01;29;21 - 00;01;56;14
Witalij
Let's examine the engineering behind the new UI5-create-app feature in Joule. for SAP Build Code. Let's start by interest.co.nz in his recent blog post. So the team treated the LLM like a true agent. First, define the goal. Second, specify the tools and constraints. Third, shallots relevant project context. And then let the model reason its way to a solution.

00;01;56;16 - 00;02;33;13
Witalij
Tool analyzes user requirements. Gathers project details like folder structure, CAP services, git state and returns a hidden Json configuration that drives deterministic template generation after app creation. Deterministic code takes over for tasks like dependency setup, while the other lamp shifts into the guidance node. The key lessons for everyone building developer tooling combined, other than flexibility, is precise tooling and strong context to deliver a smart developer experience and use deterministic code for everything predictable.

00;02;33;16 - 00;02;40;24
Witalij
For the full architecture and deeper insights. Check out the original article on SAP community.

00;02;40;26 - 00;03;09;10
DJ
One of my favorite command line tools. The BTP CLI has just had an upgrade. It's in the form of a new group, a command group to manage destinations. So alongside accounts, services and security, there's now a new group connectivity with various objects to help you manage destinations. These new objects are experimental and the BTP CLI team would love to hear from you to hear your feedback.

00;03;09;13 - 00;03;24;15
DJ
Just use as usual the BTP feedback command to trigger that link to the documentation for the new objects is in the description.

00;03;24;17 - 00;03;51;14
Witalij
We are pleased to announce the launch of Data Architecture Learning Journey. The first fundamental stage of the becoming a data Architect curriculum. The structured program covers four units. Unit one focuses on foundational concept, data modeling, metadata management, and alignment with frameworks like Segment and Target unit to explore model paradigms including data mesh, Data fabric, Data Lake, and Lakehouse.

00;03;51;16 - 00;04;25;08
Witalij
Alongside integration methods like ETL or ELT. Unit three addresses governance, security and strategic impact, including stewardship, data, lineage, and compliance for AI and ML. While unit four develops communication and leadership skills to articulate the architectural value and drive change design for data engineers, architect and IT specialists. This journey builds expertise from theory to strategic application. It also prepares you for the upcoming SAP Certified Data Architect specialization in 2026.

00;04;25;11 - 00;04;30;24
Witalij
And on that. And let us know what you think.

00;04;30;26 - 00;04;58;14
Various
I'm on my way to SAP TechEd Berlin. See you in Berlin. See you in Berlin. See you in Berlin. In Berlin. Berlin.

00;04;58;17 - 00;05;30;11
Various
Hey!

00;05;30;14 - 00;05;35;11

entry.title: Re: Confirmation of combined Orders in Mill_OC
entry.content:
Hi BHBCK - When you combined your orders using MILL_OC I assume that after combining the orders you also combined your first 10 operations only. You did not combine the subsequent operations.  After you use COHV to mass release all of the orders in the combination (the 1 lead/header order and all of the children orders) you will confirm your header order first to confirm your common operations. Then each child order "goes its own way" and you confirm them separately. The final operation of your child orders will have the goods receipts for each product you are making.  The header order likely has the 261 movement of the raw material.  

I am also new to MILL Products but the steps I described above work for us.

What is a big pain/surprise is that we cannot use CO19 Time Event confirmations; we must use CO11N Time Ticket confirmations.  The SAP Help does not say this.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere & Google BigQuery: 3 Integration Strategies Before Zero Copy via BDC Connect Arrives
entry.content:
Hello guys, how are you?

SAP and Google announced at the last SAP Connect that in H1-2026 we will have Zero Copy using BDC connect between SAP Business Data Cloud and Google BigQuery.

 

Today, our Databricks zero-copy strategy is powered by Delta Sharing. This technology, created by Databricks, enables the secure and rapid sharing of data stored in Delta Lake without the need for file replication.

What is Delta Share / Zero Copy ?

Imagine you have a Data Lake (full of Parquet, CSV, JSON files, etc.).

Then someone comes along and says

"Hey, I need access to this data!"

Normally, you would have to:

  • send the files (copies),
  • or grant access to the storage,
  • or create an API.

Delta Share / Zero Copy simplifies this:

It allows you to share data directly from Delta Lake, in Delta Table format, without moving the files. The recipient of access can read the data live, as if it were a local table â€” and with:

  • security (permission control),
  • consistency (no one gets corrupted or incomplete data),
  • and automatic updates (if the data changes, the consumer sees the updated version).

We can find more information about Zero Copy with Google BigQuery at this link : https://news.sap.com/2025/10/sap-google-cloud-redefine-enterprise-ai-zero-copy-data-google-bigquery/

However, until this connector is available, we can currently use three methods to integrate SAP Datasphere and Google Big Query, which are:

  • Data Federation: Google BigQuery -> SAP Datasphere
  • Data Federation: SAP Datasphere -> Google BigQuery
  • SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google BigQuery

First, what is data federation?

Data federation is an approach that allows access to and querying of information stored in different sources without needing to move or duplicate that data to a single repository. Instead of making copies, federation creates a virtual layer that connects systems and allows data to be consumed in real time, directly from its origins. In the context of SAP Datasphere, data federation allows the integration of external platformsâ€”such as Google BigQuery, AWS Athena, or Azure Synapseâ€”keeping the data where it is, but with the ability to combine and analyze it along with information from the SAP ecosystem. This approach reduces redundancies, improves governance, and ensures always up-to-date access to information, without sacrificing performance and security.

1. Data Federation : Google Big Query ->  SAP Datasphere

The federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access BigQuery data directly in SAP Datasphere without replicating the data, creating virtual tables that aggregate data from different sources without duplicating them. (link : https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/data-federation-in-datasphere/ba-p/13750166 )

Example : 

A common scenario would be a company that has transactional data in SAP S/4HANA and market analysis data in Google BigQuery. Through federation, you can create views that combine sales data from SAP with market trend data from BigQuery, enabling integrated analysis without moving the data from their original locations. The result is a unified view of the data that can be consumed by SAP Analytics Cloud for visualizations and reporting.

 

Below are some steps to use this architecture:

1 - Configure Google BigQuery in SAP Datasphere.

2 - Select the table from SAP BigQuery and import its metadata into SAP Datasphere.

3 - Creating a model by combining data from SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery.

 

Here at the Discovery Center, you have a step-by-step guide on how to configure and access Google BigQuery data federation in SAP Datasphere. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/3409/?tab=projectboard

Advantages of this approach

  1. Unified analytics - You combine BigQuery data with SAP information (ERP, BW, HANA, etc.) in a single analytical environment.
  1. No data movement - SAP Datasphere accesses data directly from BigQueryâ€”no copies, ETL, or extra storage costs.
  1. Real-time access - Queries reflect the most recent BigQuery data, always up-to-date.
  1. Preserved governance and security - Google Cloud access and control rules remain in effect, ensuring end-to-end security.
  1. Use of the SAP ecosystem - Allows you to use SAP Datasphere resources (modeling, Data Marketplace, SAP semantics) with BigQuery data.
  2. Scalability and performance - SAP Datasphere leverages BigQuery performance for federated queries on large volumes of data.
  3. Simpler and more flexible architecture - Fewer integrations and pipelinesâ€”you choose when to federate or, if you prefer, materialize the data in SAP.

2.  Data Federation :  SAP Datasphere -> Google Big Query

This approach to data federation between SAP Datasphere and Google BigQuery allows you to access data from SAP Datasphere directly in Google BigQuery without replicating the data, or, if you prefer, materializing the data in SAP.

For this approach, we configured a federated SAP HANA connection in Google BigQuery with these steps:

Step 1 - Create a user database in an SAP Datasphere space

Step 2 - Enable the "Expose for consumption" toggle in the SAP Datasphere view

Step 3 - Create the federated connection within Google BigQuery

Step 4 - Create a federated query in Google BigQuery

 

Step 1 - Create a user database in an SAP Datasphere space

In this step, we will create a database user in SAP Datasphere.

To do this, click on SPACE Management and then on the space where you are creating your objects, clicking on EDIT.

 

Click on the Database Access section.

In Database user, click CREATE.

Enter the username and check the ENABLE READ SQL box as shown in the image below, then click create.

Save and then deploy it.

After deployment is complete, the user will be ready to use the system. Click the "I" icon to retrieve the user's credentials.

Click on Request new password to obtain the password generated by Datasphere:

Save the information for later use.

 

Step 2 - Enable the "Expose for consumption" toggle in the SAP Datasphere view

Open the view you want to access in Google BigQuery and enable the "expose for consumption" toggle, as shown in the image below.

 

Step 3 - Create the federated connection within Google BigQuery

In Google Big Query, click on connection

 

Click on Create Connection

Select SAP HANA and configure the endpoint with the user database created in the first step;

 

Step 4 - Create a federated query in Google BigQuery

With this configuration, we can access the SAP Datasphere views that have the "expose for consumption" toggle enabled directly in Google BigQuery, as shown in the query below:

 

SELECT * FROM EXTERNAL_QUERY("XXX.us.DATASPHERE", "SELECT * FROM FINANCIAL_USER.V_FIXED_ASSET");

 

Advantages of this approach

  1. Centralized analytics - You query SAP data directly in BigQuery, along with other sources (Google Ads, CRM, etc.), all in one place.
  1. No data duplication - Data remains in SAP, avoiding copies, storage costs, and ETL pipelines.
  1. Real-time access - Queries read data directly from the sourceâ€”always up-to-date, without waiting for nightly loads.
  1. Maintained governance - SAP security and access rules are respected; BigQuery only reads what is permitted.
  1. Use of Google tools - Allows you to use the Google ecosystem (Looker, Vertex AI, Dataform, etc.) with SAP data, without moving anything. 
  1. Scalability and performance - BigQuery processes heavy queries quickly, even with large volumes of federated data.
  2. Simpler and more flexible architecture - Fewer integrations, less maintenance, and freedom to decide what to federate or materialize.

 

3.  SAP HANA ML or FED ML in Jupyter Notebooks embedded in Google Big Query

In this approach, we can transform a table or query from SAP Datasphere into a dataframe directly in Google BigQuery.

What are these libraries?

Firstly, hana-ml library is a Python client library that allows data scientists to access SAP HANA data and build machine learning models using the data directly in SAP HANA, without needing to move data between the server and the client. The library provides a Python interface to SAP HANA's machine learning capabilities, including access to the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL) and Automated Predictive Library (APL) algorithms. (https://pypi.org/project/hana-ml/)

FED ML, or Federated Machine Learning, is a Python library developed to solve a specific problem: connecting SAP business data to external Artificial Intelligence environments (Hyperscalers) efficiently and without excessive duplication. This library allows Data Scientists to work on platforms like AWS SageMaker, Azure ML, or Google Vertex AI, using open-source libraries (such as TensorFlow, PyTorch, or Scikit-learn), consuming data directly from SAP Datasphere without the need to create complex ETL (Extraction, Transformation, and Loading) pipelines. (https://github.com/SAP-samples/datasphere-fedml ).

Below is an example using the Jupyter notebook from Google Big Query consuming an object from SAP Datasphere with the hana-ml library.

To Create a Jupyter Notebook in Bigquery, click on Notebook

And then New Notebook

First, let's install the hana-ml library.

 

pip install hana-ml

Import HANA ML library 

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import hana_ml.dataframe as dataframe

Establish a connection to SAP Datasphere with the credential created in the step above:

 

import hana_ml.dataframe as dataframe

conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address='xxxxxxxxx.hana.prod-xx.hanacloud.ondemand.com', port=443,user='FINANCIAL_USER#DEMOBQ')
                                 
conn.connection.isconnected()

 

Add the table to a DataFrame.

df_sales_document_ml = conn.table("V_SALESDOCUMENT_ML_SHARED", schema="FINANCIAL_USER")

Result :

Now, you can use this object within the Jupyter notebook embedded in Google BigQuery and combine this data with data from Google BigQuery.

 

Advantages of this approach

 

  1. Unified View (360Âº) - You cross-reference financial and inventory data from SAP with behavioral and marketing data from Google (Analytics, Ads) in the same notebook, creating much richer predictive models.
  1. Elastic Infrastructure - You train heavyweight models using the  Google cloud (including GPUs), without crashing your local computer or depending on its limited memory.
  2. Accelerated AI Cycle - The developed model can quickly become a service (API), as the development environment is already integrated with the production and governance tools of Google Vertex AI.

 

Conclusion

In this blog, we explore 3 ways to integrate SAP Datasphere with Google BigQuery, serving as robust alternatives until the arrival of 'Zero Copy' functionality via BDC Connect, scheduled for the first half of 2026.

entry.title: Designing for the Humans Behind Internal Tools: My Experience in a B2B Product Environment
entry.content:
When people think about product design, they often picture sleek consumer apps, playful micro-interactions, and interfaces built to impress. But designing internal tools in a B2B setup is a completely different world, more quieter, deeper, and far more complex world. In my time working on internal enterprise tools at SAP, I learned that clarity is not just a design principle; itâ€™s a lifeline. And behind every â€œinternal userâ€ is a human trying to do their job without friction.

Internal tools may never appear on marketing websites, but their impact is profound. They influence efficiency, accuracy, and the emotional experience of employees who rely on them day after day. That realization shifted not just how I designed, but how I listened, observed, and empathized.

Seeing the Humans Behind the Screens

Itâ€™s easy to assume that internal users are experts who already know every acronym, every workflow, and every hidden rule. But the reality is different. Internal tools are often dense, legacy-driven, and layered with years of business logic. Even experienced users can feel lost.

The biggest shift in my approach was treating internal users with the same empathy we give external customers. They deserve legibility, emotional ease, and moments of clarity just as much , if not more. Internal users donâ€™t get guided onboarding videos or marketing-style product tours. They jump straight into complex systems, often juggling multiple responsibilities at once. Designing with this in mind meant prioritizing legibility, reducing mental effort, and ensuring every step felt intentional and supportive. It also meant acknowledging emotional factors : the frustration caused by unclear pathways, the hesitation before clicking a critical button, or the relief when a workflow simply â€œmakes sense.â€

Why always design for a First-Time User ?

One of the most impactful parts of my work was dissecting user flows not from the perspective of a product expert, but from that of a normal user behind the screen. This meant breaking down each step, identifying friction areas, and asking:

  • Would this make sense on the first try?

  • Where might someone hesitate?

  • Is the next step predictable?

This approach helped uncover pain points that would otherwise be overlooked. Redesigning flows with the same energy and curiosity that we bring to complex edge cases ensured a more holistic experience for everyone , not just the power users. Explanations should never be a one-time thing. Interfaces evolve, workflows change, and users switch contexts constantly, which means even product experts can feel like first-time users on any given day. Clear guidance, consistent cues, and small but intentional pieces of always-available information prevent friction before it appears. Designing for first-time users doesnâ€™t mean oversimplifying; it means making the experience understandable without assumptions. A little more clarity is never unhelpful. It builds confidence, reduces cognitive load, and ensures that whether someone is new or highly experienced, the UI supports them with the same level of care every time they return.

Designing for Understanding, Not Just Completion

Clarity became a central part of the user experience. Often, this meant advocating for simple but powerful additions:

  • Tooltips to explain complex business terms

  • Message strips that guide users on what to do next

  • Inline cues to reduce ambiguity

Even closure points became important. Adding a gentle toast message confirming the end of a workflow gave users a sense of completion and confidence. In internal tools, these small reinforcements make tasks more predictable and emotionally easier. These were not ornamental additions : they were essential interactions that reduced ambiguity in critical workflows. Even something as small as a well-placed tooltip could prevent misinterpretation and save users from repeated trial-and-error. Designing for internal systems reminded me that user attention is valuable; it should not be spent deciphering jargon or guessing next steps.

Making Business Language Human-Friendly

Internal tools are filled with terminology that can overwhelm even experienced users. Improving the legibility of business terms becomes a core part of designing for internal tools. Content design is as much needed as the user experience of the workflows.  Good internal design is a culmination of creating easy simplified workflows and making them understandable without extra training. Hence, improving business term legibility became a central part of my design work. Simplifying labels, rephrasing instructions, and breaking down complex concepts helped users focus on their tasks rather than decoding language.

Bringing Stakeholders Into the Process

Another crucial element was transparency with stakeholders â€” product managers, engineering managers, and other decision-makers. For every major initiative, I created structured process documents that offered:

  • A clear overview of the problem

  • The user journey and its pain points

  • Research findings and insights

  • Iteration timelines

  • Rationale behind each design decision

This level of clarity helped build alignment, earned trust, and ensured everyone understood why a design change mattered. It also strengthened the collaboration between design, product, and engineering.  Stakeholders could see the depth of research, empathize with user pain points, and understand why certain design choices were necessary. It transformed conversations from subjective opinions into grounded, user-informed discussions. In many cases, it became a shared reference point that made decision-making faster and more evidence-driven.

The Quiet Impact of Good Internal Design

Working on internal tools taught me that designâ€™s impact is often invisible but deeply felt. When internal workflows are smooth:

Work becomes faster, with fewer interruptions.
Errors decrease because the system is easier to understand.
Confidence rises as users feel supported instead of overwhelmed.
And most importantly, work becomes less stressful.

These are the small, quiet victories of internal product design. They donâ€™t show up on landing pages, but they shape the everyday work life of employees across the organisation. Designing internal tools reminded me that design is ultimately about understanding people and even when the tools are not customer-facing. Especially then.

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors Time Off 2026 leave balance
entry.content:
Hi @s0026444332 

For your requirements it is possible to achieve with 2 scenarios.

1. Automation

 In the time account type configuration, set the "Account Creation Automation" and "Level Of Accrual Automation" as "Automatic creation" and define the required "Account Creation Offset [Months]" as "-1" so the account gets created in previous  year December and "Accrual Creation Offset [Days]" as "-25" so the accrual happens after the account creation. 

Duration for account creation and accrual creation can be customized, always account creation has to happen in prior to accrual.

Based on the configuration, auto scheduler will be created in Time Off calendar and gets executed on it's own.

2. Manual Accrual run

In Time Off calendar, you have to run the job manually in advance for account creation and accrual execution in much advance to the year end. 

So users can able to view the next year account along with balance in advance.

Thanks

Arun

entry.title: Re: Can't open Installation due to the error "User does n...
entry.content:
The reason you are unable to access the provided installation number is due to the absence of the required authorization. As outlined in KBA 3469559 - Authorization required to view my company's installation numbers - SAP for Me. 

To resolve this issue, you can request the necessary authorizations by contacting your company's Super Administrators, whose details can be found in https://me.sap.com/userscontacts/impcont, or use the self-service request according to KBA 2891528 - How to use the Self-Service Authorization Request - SAP for Me.

entry.title: Recommendation/Best Practice for SAP Master Data Governance Extensibility in Classic Mode
entry.content:
Introduction to Clean Core in S/4HANA

With the introduction of MDG Cloud Ready Mode in SAP S/4HANA 2023, SAP has significantly intensified its emphasis on maintaining a clean core. SAPâ€™s objective is clear: Organizations must transition toward a clean core, a system landscape where customizations are isolated from the core application, ensuring long-term stability, predictable upgrades, and seamless adoption of innovations delivered by SAP.

Customers opting for Cloud Ready Mode encounter stricter guardrails around extensibility. Traditional enhancement patternsâ€”such as modifications, implicit enhancements, or pervasive use of custom code within standard classesâ€”are heavily restricted. Only those extension approaches that guarantee lifecycle stability and upgrade resilience are supported.

Implications for MDG Customers in Classic Mode

For organizations currently using MDG in Classic Mode, but intending to maintain system stability and ensure smooth, low-effort upgrades, it becomes essential to adopt an extension strategy that aligns closely with clean-core guidelines. The extension approach must strike a balance between functional requirements and long-term maintainability, particularly in upgrade-intensive environments.

Organizations in Classic Mode face pressing questions:

  • How do we continue enhancing MDG without jeopardizing upgrade stability?
  • Which extensibility options remain viable, and which should be avoided?
  • How can we design custom logic that aligns with SAPâ€™s forward-looking roadmap?
  • What development patterns minimize rework in future upgrades?

Recommended Extensibility Approach

Following SAPâ€™s clean-core philosophy, the recommended extensibility hierarchy is as follows:

1. Key User In-App Extensibility

Preferred for UI and lightweight business logic enhancements, designed to be upgrade-safe and lifecycle-stable

2. Side-by-Side Extensibility

Ideal for more complex or custom business processes using SAP BTP, providing isolation from the S/4HANA digital core while ensuring deep integration through released APIs and events

3. Classic Extensibility

Classic extensions remain available in MDG Classic Mode, but they should be used sparingly and only when clean-core options cannot fulfil the requirement.

Classic extensibility includes:

  • BADIs specific to MDG
  • Enhancement points
  • Derivation and validation exits
  • Custom code within allowed enhancement frameworks

Considerations for MDG Extension Design

There have been attempts in Classic Mode to build wrapper classes around SAP standard MDG classes with the intention of stabilizing custom logic across upgrades. However, given the expanding set of released APIs and whitelisted objects, attempting to wrap all MDG-specific classes is time-consuming.

A more sustainable approach is to rely on:

  • Released MDG APIs, frameworks, and BAdIs
  • Workflow and rule-based configurability
  • Event-driven extension patterns via SAP BTP
  • Governance processes aligned with clean-core principles

 

Below table will outline the recommended and prioritized extension options for MDG in Classic Mode, offering guidance for customers seeking to preserve upgrade stability while aligning with SAPâ€™s recommended enhancement strategy.

We will continue to revise and update the above list, as and when new scenarios and capabilities are identified.

entry.title: Why 345% ROI Is Possible â€” When ERP Modules Talk: The Power of SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Article Teaser:
Integration reduces cost and risk when ERP modules and third-party systems share data reliably. SAP Integration Suite provides the platform, patterns, and tooling to connect modules, cut manual work, and deliver large returns over time.

Overview: Why Module Integration Matters

Disconnected modules create duplicate data, delayed processes, and manual reconciliation. Integration turns isolated systems into coordinated services. When ERP, CRM, SCM, HR, and analytics speak the same language, teams act faster and errors drop.

What SAP Integration Suite Provides

  • Prebuilt adapters and connectors: ready integrations for SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, and common third-party systems.
  • API management: central lifecycle control for APIs, security policies, and rate limits.
  • Event-driven architecture: support for asynchronous messaging, event mesh, and reactive flows.
  • Orchestration and mapping: design integration flows with transformation, enrichment, and routing.
  • Hybrid support: secure connectivity across cloud and on-prem landscapes via Cloud Connector.

Key Integration Patterns

Architects should choose patterns based on latency, consistency needs, and transaction scope:

  • Request-Reply (synchronous): use for immediate user-facing operations where response time is critical.
  • Event Notification (asynchronous): preferred for decoupling systems and scaling; use event mesh and durable queues.
  • Change Data Capture (CDC): publish database changes to downstream consumers to keep data near real-time without heavy ETL.
  • SAGA (compensation): implement long-running business transactions that require distributed rollback logic.
  • API FaÃ§ade: present a single, stable API for consumers while hiding backend module changes.

Technical Best Practices

  • Model canonical data: create a canonical schema to reduce mappings and preserve business meaning across modules.
  • Idempotent operations: design endpoints so retries do not cause duplicate side effects.
  • Secure by design: enforce OAuth2, mTLS for connectors, and strict role-based access control for APIs.
  • Error handling and observability: centralize logs, traces, and metrics; alert on integration latency and message loss.
  • Performance tuning: right-size virtual warehouses/containers, parallelize transforms, and push down heavy transformations to the database or target engine.
  • CI/CD for integrations: store integration flows and mapping specs in Git, run automated tests, and use blue/green or canary deploys for runtime changes.

Data Consistency and Latency Tradeoffs

Designers must choose consistency vs. latency:

  • Strong consistency: synchronous calls or transactional bridging; suitable for payment or ledger updates.
  • Eventual consistency: asynchronous updates that converge over time; ideal for inventory snapshots, reporting, and analytics.

Use CDC plus materialized views or near-real-time caches to give analytics systems fresh data without burdening operational databases.

Security, Governance, and Compliance

Integration increases the attack surface. Lock it down:

  • Use centralized API gateway policies for authentication, authorization, and threat protection.
  • Implement data masking and field-level encryption for sensitive attributes.
  • Log lineage and provide traceability for audit and compliance requirements.
  • Apply tenant and region isolation when handling multi-country data to meet local data residency rules.

Measuring Value: Where the ROI Comes From

Integration Suite delivers measurable gains across three areas:

  • Cost reduction: fewer point-to-point interfaces, reduced manual reconciliation, lower middleware licensing, and ops overhead.
  • Process acceleration: automated order flows, faster settlement, and reduced lead time â€” speeding cash conversion cycles.
  • Decision speed: near-real-time data for analytics reduces decision latency and avoids costly delays.

Studies and vendor analyses have reported combined ROI figures (including hard and soft benefits) in the hundreds of percent over a 2â€“3 year horizon for well-executed integrations. The exact figure depends on scale, baseline inefficiency, and scope of automation.

Realistic Implementation Roadmap

  1. Assess and map: inventory systems, data models, and business events across modules.
  2. Define canonical model: pick core entities and common taxonomy.
  3. Prioritize flows: start with high-value, low-risk integrations (e.g., order-to-cash or procure-to-pay).
  4. Build with prebuilt connectors: use Integration Suite adapters and API Management to accelerate delivery.
  5. Automate testing and observability: validate data accuracy and monitor SLAs.
  6. Scale and govern: iterate, add event patterns, and enforce governance guards.

Common Pitfalls to Avoid

  • Building point-to-point integrations without a strategy leads to brittle landscapes.
  • Neglecting data modeling increases mapping complexity and runtime errors.
  • Underestimating governance creates security and compliance drift.
  • Rushing to synchronous designs for all flows harms scalability.

Conclusion

SAP Integration Suite is not just middleware. It is a strategic layer that enables modules to operate as a cohesive, responsive enterprise. With the right architecture, design patterns, and governance, organizations replace manual effort with automated flows and convert integration into measurable business value. That is how significant ROI numbers become achievable.

Engage Further

If you want implementation examples, reference architectures, or a checklist for your first five integration flows, ask here or share your environment details. Iâ€™ll post a template you can adapt.
